Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the St. Regis Jan 14-17. Given some of the poor reviews I've read, I was prepared to be (very) disappointed. Overall, the experience was very good and, given the staff's general willing and friendly attitude, I think that the resort will probably achieve it's full potential if there is a little more focus on a few small things. What's great: 1. The rooms 2. The grounds 3. The staff really wants to be helpful 4. One of the nicest spas I have seen--beautiful aesthetically and the first time I have been offerred champagne while I wait for a treatment. Highly recommend. 5. With one exception where we waited for tea to be delivered for 45 minutes, the butler service was attentive and prompt. What's so-so: 1. The prices. Nothing is cheap here ($22 hamburgers, etc.). That said, I think the prices are pretty close to what you would find at other St. Regis, Four Seasons, Ritz Carlton hotels. 2. The restaurants: Food is fine but generally not spectacular. I tried all 3 and all 3 were good but not great. 3. The beach: The beach is nice and very private but it is definitely not the most amazing beach in the world. The quality of the sand is ok but not powdery soft and the surf can be rough (parents of small children should be cautious). What could use improvement: 1. When we checked in at around 1:30pm, our room was not ready, which I am fine with given that checkin is at 3pm. We were told to leave our cell phone number and they would call once the room was ready. At 4pm, we still had not heard anything and went back to the front desk. We were given a room at that point but there was no great explanation as to why we hadn't been called earlier. 2. Pool/beach service can be uneven. For two days, we had a great server who made regular rounds to see what we needed. On the third day, it was almost impossible to get served. 3. We had read about the $60 resort charge and knew to expect it. That said, a property of this caliber should not be adding a resort charge. If they need the extra $60, please add it to the room rates. It feels a little sleazy. 4. Gratuity added automatically. For almost anything, the hotel automatically adds a 18-20% gratuity. That is certainly not standard practice in the US and I find it a little presumptuous. 5. No newspaper even though we were supposed to receive it daily. 6. While I did not find the pool to be frigid as some reviewers have posted, it was a little on the cold side--it should be heated. What we did not evaluate: 1. Golf 2. Housekeeping: Given the horror stories, I decided to call when I left the room. The room was always made up when we returned. Evening turndown service was provided each night without me asking. 3. Concierge: we did not use their services

Reviews.Title: “Overall great stay ... But not just quite there yet.”
Reviews.Author: Ironlungs
Reviews.Content: My wife and I recently stayed at the St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort in Puerto Rico for 5 nights from January 6th - 11th. To provide some background/context for this review, we are in our early 30s and planned this vacation specifically for relaxation purposes while our 2 year-old daughter remained at home with my in-laws. We do stay at high-end resorts but by all means, it is not always a necessity. Overall, we had a wonderful time at the St. Regis and it is a place that we would recommend quite highly; the amenities were excellent, the activities available are varied and the property is beautiful, expansive, unique, secluded and intimate. From what we have seen, this is also a very family friendly resort with sources of outdoor entertainment for young children. In fact, there were many couples visiting with young kids and teenagers; therefore, if you have issues with kids at the pool side or children at the dinner table (no matter how fancy it is), you will surely be disappointed. Personally, we did not mind it a bit having been in that situation before and we actually appreciated the laid back atmosphere. Despite the fact that we had a great overall experience, there were inconsistencies within our stay that still need to be resolved by the management and I will address this at the end. After reading some of the earlier mixed and negative reviews here, we were admittedly apprehensive. However, it is apparent that the staff and management have perhaps reviewed the feedback and criticism and have made efforts to rectify the majority of the issues that earlier guests have pointed out. In terms of the resort itself, it is expansive, quiet, intimate and quite beautiful. There are various activities available on the premises including kayaking, fishing, golfing and tennis. This is clearly a place meant for those people who want to have a quiet and peaceful time for relaxation and reading by the beach or pool. If you get bored easily or if you require entertainment, this may not be the right place for you. We were perfectly content. In terms of transportation, there is reportedly a car service available to take you from and to the airport for $120 each way. My understanding is that there are taxis/transportation services from the resort to San Juan as well although I do not know the cost. We rented a car through Enterprise for 5 days for $120 flat. Of course, there is a $20/night valet fee for parking at the St. Regis; therefore, the cost of renting vs. using their services is a wash in my opinion. If I had to do it over again, I probably would not have rented a car given that we used it only for 1 day to travel to San Juan and ended up wanting to spend as much time as we could at the resort itself. For families with kids, it may make some sense to rent a car to acquire supplies at the local supermarket (Ralph's) given the price of simple products such as milk or juice at the resort. In addition, the drive is quite simple and straightforward. The rooms quite nice with enormous showers and a soaking tub. We stayed in a room with a garden view with a private balcony. There are Ocean View suites available as well but because we arrived during a week where the resort was booked, there were no opportunities to upgrade but definitely ask. In terms of food, there are three restaurants at the resort: 1. Seagrapes 2. Fern 3. Molasses (Located by the golf course; we did not dine here). Menus are all available online. Seagrapes is located by the pool and overlooks the beach. Lunch is very relaxed, laid-back and 'beachy' whereas dinner is a bit more formal and a live band provides entertainment. The lunch menu is quite eclectic and consists of flat bread pizzas (very good -- the piquant sausage w/ garlic was excellent), salads and sandwiches. The dinner entrees consisted of various seafood items including halibut, grouper, and salmon. Wagyu steak was an option as well. Lunch items range from $17-$26 while dinner entrees range from $24-38. Cocktails are $15 which is the typical cost of a drink at a NYC hotel bar so albeit pricey, not unexpected for us. By the way, the cocktails are incredible. To summarize, the lunch options are great for a day at the beach but dinner is 'average' at Seagrapes. Fern is Jean-George's restaurant at the resort which consists of 'fusion' contemporary cuisine. The atmosphere is a bit more sophisticated but not stuffy. Meals can be eaten either inside the dining room or outside on the balcony overlooking the main lawn and the ocean. During the day, the ocean breeze and view really made our breakfast and brunch absolutely perfect. At Fern, the brunch and breakfast is not to be missed --- I ordered Eggs Benedict over smoked salmon every day; it was definitely the best meal of the day but the view played a large role. Dinner was good and consistent. It was definitely not the best cuisine we've had (we lived in NYC for many years so we have been to some great places) but it was consistent, well seasoned, and satisfying -- nothing particularly special. Service was spotty at times (waiters not filling the water, incorrect items on our bill, providing dessert menus in a very untimely manner etc.) but our waiter did thank us for our patience at one point without prompting and even though this was a small gesture, it went a long way for me. We ordered Room Service two of the nights because we could not get reservations at Fern and did not want to have dinner at Seagrapes every night. One reviewer commented that the menu 'was a joke' which I didn't understand as it appears to be very similar to other high-end resorts and hotels in general. The menu is similar to that of Seagrapes including red snapper ceviche, burgers, grilled salmon, gnocchi, etc. The food was mediocre and the portion size was a bit small. However, it's room service --- I have low expectations to start. The only issue I had was the staff fielding the orders --- the first night, the woman taking our order was excellent and knew the menu quite well, even items not on the menu. During the second night, the woman taking our order was clueless. As noted previously, be prepared to pay for extra fees associated with room service --- this includes a $5 delivery charge and a 22% service charge + tax (17% of the service charge goes into the tip) Final Recommendations/Advice for Food at your stay at the St. Regis: 1. Request 'butler' order morning coffee to be delivered at a specific time to your door on a daily basis rather than using the in-room coffee markers. We learned about this from previous reviewers on Tripadvisor. It is complimentary and 100 x better given that it is made in a French Press. Coffee over your terrace or ocean view is the best way to start the morning. 2. Seagrapes is excellent for a satisfying meal at the beach or poolside. Be aware that a 18% tip is already included into the bill; Our server was kind of enough to point this out the first day we arrived. 3. Consider going to Fern for breakfast or brunch every morning --- it's worth it both for the food and ambience; Dine on the terrace overlooking the ocean; I regret that we did not do this from day one. 4. Consider going to Fern for most of your meals --- Seagrapes became tiresome after a while. I would skip out on room service. If I had to do it all over again, I probably would've skipped dinner at Seagrapes and proceeded to go to dinner every night at Fern instead (if there are openings; BTW - you can book reservations through Open Table and it is encouraged that you do so ahead of time; we didn't think when we first arrived that reservations would be necessary at all but we were wrong. Overall, the cost difference is neglible and the food is much superior than that of Seagrapes. Spa: My wife received a prenatal massage at $165. There have been complaints about the cost but when we used to live in NYC, this was the typical cost of a 1 hour massage at the Elizabeth Arden Red Door Spa so we did not think that it was unreasonable for a resort (in contrast to that of the Mandarin Oriental where it can be around $250 per hour). Per her report, she had a wonderful experience. Apparently, from the outside, it is rather inconspicuous but upon entering, it was beautiful, comfortable, and luxurious ... this is coming from some one who has had many massages in her lifetime. "Well worth it" was her comment. Main Issues/Complaints: Overall, we were happy with our stay. However, there are clearly some issues that still need to be sorted out. We felt that the service was overall excellent and the staff was extremely friendly. I think that many of the concerns initially raised by reviewers have been fixed (for the most part) regarding 'clueless' staff. I found them to be quite responsive and will likely improve with a bit more time. 1. The issue regarding the air conditioning unit has been mentioned by previous reviewers and it really is a serious problem. Whoever made the decision on the air conditioning really should be fired. The management should seriously consider re-installing or re-working the A/C because it is extremely loud, to the point where my sleep was hindered. Given the humidity, A/C is essential and I enjoy sleeping in silence or gentle background noise. This A/C unit is akin to a jet plane engine (a bit of hyperbole but really, not overly so) 2. Spotty and inconsistent service with clean-up by the suites. We didn't experience the housekeeping others did. We had our beds cleaned, shampoo replenished and beds turned out in the afternoon. One issue that I had was various laundry baskets left in the hallway and the fact that our breakfast coffee trays were left outside our door ... all day. It appeared at times that no know knew who was truly responsible for the pick-up. The 'little things' do matter. Final Impression/Recommendations: The St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort provided us everything that we wanted in a vacation. It is an amazing property with excellent service, food and ambience. It is quiet, relaxed, and private. We had a great time and would recommend it to friends and family members ... however, this is a recommendation with a caveat: If you are in need of being entertained (live entertainment, lots of activities, exciting adventures, etc.) this is not the place for you. If your goal is to relax, play some tennis and golf, go for a bike ride or to kayak, read by the pool or beach, and to enjoy some wonderful cuisine and ambience, this is the perfect place. If you have children, it is indeed family friendly and would be a great vacation spot for teenagers and younger children (the staff is very open to having kids around; I can't say the same for the guests) Finally, if you are the type of individual who demands exceptional service and consistently stay at 'the best places possible' I am certain that as is, it will not live up to your expectations and you will be disappointed. For those who are a bit more laid back, I do think that with a little more time and a few additional adjustments, the staff and the amenities will improve and it will be a truly great place to stay in Puerto Rico.

Reviews.Title: “I wanted to stay longer...”
Reviews.Author: KM_Borowski
Reviews.Content: Amazing staff - bellman, butler and pool employees were friendly and helpful. Thank you for the best face to a hotel. Comfortable room - so hard to pull myself away! Magnificent bath (tub and shower space was large - please supply bath salts); the bed was made with just the right amount of pillows and tasteful linens; elegant mini bar; perfect lounge furniture on the balcony. Misses - reception had only one staff member at check in and out which lead to a line and wasted time (I asked if other staff could be found but they weren't); the concierge was not interested in supplying information - I only got answers to my specific questions; Fern - book a table in advance if you must go. Upon arrival we were told it was fully booked and we were put on a waitlist; then when I checked around 6pm we were told they would try to accomodate us, so we hurry and get over there; and we find a nearly empty restaurant (there were empty tables all night). The menu was more limited than I had anticipated. While the dishes were nice, nothing rocked my world and I wouldn't go back. I would go back and spend more time at the pool and walking the grounds (gorgeous!). Maybe even try the spa.

Reviews.Title: “Service not close to brand standards”
Reviews.Author: globetrot873
Reviews.Content: I returned recently from a brief stay at the St. Regis Bahia Beach with my wife and young daughter. As we have visited other SR properties and are big fans of the brand, we were looking forward with great anticipation to experiencing this newest property. I am sorry to report, however, that the hotel fell far short of expectations and that I cannot recommend it to other like-minded travelers. This is a pity, certainly, since the resort grounds and public spaces are beautiful and the rooms gorgeous. Most significantly, the service culture is not up to SR standards. I frequently felt as if my requests (none of which were unreasonable) were met with resentmentâ€¦ not in an overt or aggressive manner but more subtle and guised. Examplesâ€¦ - We never met our butler. In fact, I think the entire butler program at the hotel is a giant myth and is merely an equivalent of calling the front desk at any other hotel (on multiple occasions a call to the â€œbutlerâ€� was never even picked upâ€¦.the phone just kept ringing); - I received room service 90 minutes after placing my order, and after I had already called to cancel (after waiting for 45 minutes); - Valet failed to get my car even with 20 minutes notice; - I had to request a high chair tray three times at breakfast until one was actually brought over; - Only a handful of staffers seemed to know anything about the hotel or the surrounding area: if you asked three people for directions anywhere, whether within or outside the hotel, you were likely to receive three different answers; - When I asked for an extra umbrella to be set up by us on the beach, I was told this wasnâ€™t possible, since they â€œhad already dug the holesâ€�â€¦ and this despite the fact that the beach was sparsely populated and there were plenty of umbrellas for the taking. A different attendant, sensing my frustration, finally brought over a second umbrella. Aside from its service culture, the hotel also needs to address two other major shortcomings: - The pool isnâ€™t heated! At a resort as isolated as the SR, where there isnâ€™t much to do but lounge by the pool, it needs to be swimmable. Instead, itâ€™s absolutely freezing (at least in January when temperatures hover around 80). - The food outside of Fern (the Jean-Gorges restaurant) is mediocre. A â€œCaesar salad with baked crispâ€� consisted of bagged lettuce, boxed croutons, and bottled dressingâ€¦ and with a $17 price tag. Youâ€™re better off renting a car and sampling the local mofongo; all-in-all, itâ€™ll be a wash money-wise and a more tasty experience. The majority of the clientele for this hotel consists of Manhattanites, who are discerning and demanding by nature (and, being one, I have no shame in saying this). If the hotel wants to succeed with this population, it has serious work to do.

Reviews.Title: “Heaven on Earth!”
Reviews.Author: hpl07
Reviews.Content: This is the most beautiful Resort where we have ever stayed at and not only that but the level of service is definitely top notch. We stayed at The St. Regis for a week during the last days of 2010 and the first ones of 2011. The property, like everyone else states on these reviews, is out of this world - absolutely gorgeous. From the first to the last impression and everything in between, the experience at this new place was great. The attention to details in the magnificent rooms were extraordinary and the warmth of the staff was very much welcome. The Restaurants, their food and service were remarkable, we know that when traveling to the Caribbean we should not expect 5 star service but this place proved us wrong. Seagrapes, the Restaurant by the pool serves exquisite lunch and dinner with such gracious employees, we ate lunch there every day and our waiter would remember exactly what we liked to drink and receive us with our PiÃ±a Coladas, diet coke and sherly temples! We also had Room Service for breakfast and dinner and it wasn't only on time every time but the food was great and really hot when arriving, also the server was so accommodating and caring, my daughter would say "I really like him, he is such a nice gentleman". Fern, their upscale option for dinner was outstanding, we only had dinner there one time but again both, service and food were delicious. Of course that there are some small things that the Hotel has still to get together, which I would think are normal for such a new property, but the overall experience was definitely extremely memorable and positive. We highly recommend this place for an easy, luxurious, relaxing and full of quality vacation at the Caribbean. We will definitely be back for the summer!

Reviews.Title: “PERFECTION IN PUERTO RICO!!!!”
Reviews.Author: jms2222
Reviews.Content: I want to begin by saying that I almost cancelled my stay at this resort after reading the reviews on trip advisor just prior to my departure. I AM SO GLAD I DIDN'T!!!!! I don't know who is writing those reviews, but I am a Starwood Preferred Guest who travels frequently and only stays at luxury 5 star resorts. I admit that I am very fussy and extremely particular. From the moment "Joel" picked us up at the airport in a beautiful mercedez limo to the moment we checked out we were treated like royalty. As soon as we arrived, Maria the concierge arranged for all of our dinner reservations and excursions. The room was amazing....the bathroom shower was large enough to fit 5 people with a rainshower head. There was a TV built into the mirror over the bathroom sink..I've never seen that before!! The products were fantastic..Spa shampoos, conditioners..exfoliants..lotions..2 types of soap...loufa sponges and loufa brushes, and more. The quality and quantity was wonderful...The butler service (Vanessa and Luisa) was very helpful arranging for carts to take us to the resort restaurants, as well as serving us coffee & tea in the morning & evening (at no charge). She also brought us a selection of DVDs to choose from (at no charge). Each evening when we returned to our room, our bed was turned down and soft music was playing. We had a lovely terrace with table, chairs and a sofa to relax on with a great view of the foliage. When we arrived at the beach/pool the staff (Luis) immediately found us lounge chairs with umbrellas and laid out towels for us (not having to awaken at 7am to secure chairs like at other hotels!) The ocean was swimmable and the pool was beautiful, however not heated. I would have preferred a heated pool, however I was able to relax in the Jacuzzi which was a great temperature. The exercise equipment was top notch. The food was excellent...we had breakfast at Ferns, lunch at Seagrapes by the pool and dinner at Molasses (where I ordered Mufongo at the suggestion of "Joel"..it was fabulous!!) We are fussy eaters and the chef accomodated all our special food requests. I would like to address the issue that many people have with the prices...If you travel and stay at luxury or even mid-rate hotels you must know that hotel food is generally pricey.. You can always see the menus on-line before you book your reservation so you know what the pricing is... The food was excellent and the service top-notch..every and I mean every staff member we passed always had a smile on their face and a warm greeting. The front desk was extremely helpful when we needed to change our flight home to avoid the predicted blizzard in New York...while we were away enjoying the evening biolumenescent kayak tour, she waited for us to return at 11 PM to inform us that all the arrangements had been made!! Another example of the quality of service is when I was taking a photo by the magnificent infinity pool at the entrance to the main lobby. One of the bellhops noticed that there was a car parked in the background and without being asked..he moved the car so it wouldn't be in my picture!!!!! I was curious to find out if other guests felt the same way about their stay as I did, so I asked a woman who was leaving what she thought..she said she enjoyed her stay so much that she was returning in March!!! We also ran into an acquantance while we were there and he was also very impressed with the resort..they had upgraded him to a suite!!! In conclusion...I'd like to say that I only take the time to write a review if I feel strongly about where I've stayed.. I do want to mention that there is no casino or night activities so you would have to take a taxi to another place if that's important to you.(They do have a beautiful golf course, driving range and free boating and biking)....As I sit writing this review..looking at the snow outside...I'm thinking..maybe I shouldn't have changed that flight after all..it would have been wonderful to have one more day of warm weather and pampering!!!

Reviews.Title: “A Perfect Paradis”
Reviews.Author: Exeterbos
Reviews.Content: I have traveled to many places in the World but never have I seen anything like the St Regis Bahia Beach. While visiting friends in Puerto Rico, we had an opportunity to visit and stay at the St Regis, Bahia Beach in Rio Grande, Puerto Rico. We had been to the resort previously, to play golf with friends; however, the hotel was still under construction and had not opened. On this trip we were determined to see the facility and enjoy the offerings. We zipped down to Rio Grande on the Autopiste from San Juan . In some 20 minutes we were at the front door of the Resort, welcomed by some of the friendliest and helpful faces I have ever seen at a hotel. Bags collected and car whisked off by the Valet, we were escorted past the fire pits lining the front walkway to the Concierge for check in. Glass of champagne, Mimosa while we were taken through a pleasant registration process (remember those?), then introduced to our Butler who was to take us to our room. Normally, a bellman will escort you and your baggage to the room and it can be an experience ranging from the ridiculous to the sublime. Not at the St. Regis. Off in a golf cart you go, with the love of your life at your side, and you plunge into the jungle on a boardwalk (to protect the flowers and the fauna) and thence to your room. Very well done! One begins to unwind on the cart, pulses slowing down to match the mood of the jungle. Then in no time, literally, you pull up to your casita, and out you go, up to the room (by the way, it was a quick, simple walk from the casita to the main building Plantation House, but I would not have missed that ride for the world). Ah, what a room it is, as the Butler (who was terrific and if you have never experienced a great butler you are in for a treat. If you have one at home you may want to kidnap one of theirs) introduced us to the room and its various amenities, we were both astonished. I believe that the entry hall to our room was larger than my first apartment and certainly nicer looking. We regularly stay at five star hotels, but this room, and it was a standard room we reserved, not a suite, was an absolute show stopper, all around. We were first introduced to the sleeping area. The bed was a king and a beauty. St. Regis really does understand that the prime function of a guest room is for sleeping and relaxing while on vacation, and , the bed is critical. We are pleased to report that we lasted all of five minutes that evening once under the covers and the comforter (yes, a comforter) and slept like there was no tomorrow. However, sleep was for later, at this point we were still exploring light switch central (all controlled bedside, including the TV which is enormous and provides easy viewing from the bed, if one were able to say awake long enough once in that comfy environment. Opposite the bed, the bar. Not your typical mini bar for the St. Regis. Not at all. First, we saw the ingredients for mixing our own mojitos, including fresh mint (and a mortar and pestle to grind it with) as well as the appropriate liquors. Additionally, there were at least three types of chocolate, certainly enough to satisfy any late night cravings and a few bottles of champagne to wash the chocolate down, should one desire to do so. I did. Then there is the bath room (two words) large enough to accommodate a Celtics Game. His and her sinks were in full force, with a mirror in which one could view oneâ€™s favorite news/sports/cable program while shaving or washing up (why not-just like home) and then on to the bathing area. One wall of the bathing area (and it is quite generous) was a rain shower/ hand shower combination that proved delightful and worked perfectly. Opposite this marvel was a soaking tub that could accommodate a small aircraft carrier, and, was indeed the delight of Milady. There is a private toilet which, I must report is not only ventilated beautifully, but does not cause one to experience claustrophobia in the slightest. After unpacking, turning on and off all the electronics in the room, we left for dinner at Jean Georges. I do not know if you have had dinner at jean Georges in New York, reputed to be the best restaurant in a city replete with â€œbestâ€� restaurants. I can only say that the night we ate at Jean Georges at the St Regis, it was perfect. Not kidding. Perfect. The service was unbelievable (remember, we were nothing special, just a couple of oldsters with a penchant for good wine and food). We were absolutely blown away with the quality of food, and the ambiance of the facility. The service was some of the best I have ever received this side of Asia and the staff as friendly as one would like. After a dinner, in a restaurant overlooking the ocean, we went back to our room and thence goodnight. Ah, but the next day, the next day. We were up and at em in the morning with breakfast on the upstairs terrace of the Hotel (Jean Georges serves breakfast). Hot coffee (Puerto Rican of course) and fresh hot croissants with butter and off to golf. Now, I have found that if one is at a resort and there is an ocean, a pool and golf along with a reasonable restaurant, and a good room, I am a happy man. Rarely does one find that four are top notch, seldom all five. Well, Bahia is a five for five. If you are a golfer, you will love the course. There are only a handful of courses that have finishing holes on the Ocean and they, at least in my knowledge, can cost more than a down payment on a Ferrari. The golf course here is not only challenging, it is without doubt, the most beautiful course upon which I have ever played. Ever. And it is now firmly my world favorite. If you like Ocean, the entire resort sits on one. I mean you can simply walk across the pool or the restaurant right into the ocean, clearer and bluer than anything I have seen this side of Greece. Sensual, warm and inviting, the water literally envelopes you in its magic and its power. You will not be disappointed. After all, this is a resort in which one may relax or just be in love. I am not a pool person, not will I ever be one. But one can sun here to their heartâ€™s content by the pool, dip in the water to refresh and still hear the rush of the sea a few steps away. Not bad, eh? I must also take a moment to applaud the developer. Everywhere you look, you see the care and love this individual has taken in the creation of this magnificent, world class resort. One cannot but help to be impressed that such a spectacular development was created , while all the while taking into great concern the environment and the animals that inhabit it (yes, there are birds and creatures everywhere, if one takes the time to look and see them) in juxtaposition with us. Puerto Rico now has a destination within a destination that sets the standard for what a top end resort should be. If I were you and my significant other was beginning to feel the doldrums of winter, I would suggest the following. Make a reservation at the St Regis, book a couple of tickets and surprise the love of your life with a few days in Paradise. I can assure you the reward will be worth it. And, oh yes, no passport needed. Go.

Reviews.Title: “beautiful if you want to relax to the point of boredom”
Reviews.Author: artistoftheworld
Reviews.Content: THis property is beautiful, and the staff very nice. But----the place needs some activities such as a live music or some sort of entertainment. The rooms are extra large and gorgeous but the service was not up to St Regis reputation. The hotel has a shuttle to San Juan for $120 each way! This place is so far out that if you don't eat at one of their 2 restaurants you are at the mercy of their very expensive car service or some cab drivers who don't know where it is. I would only recommend this property to someone who wanted total privacy and a quiet restful stay. The think that really got us was after spending 6 days there we wanted to check out and use the pool until our evening flight. We were told we could not take a shower on the proerty ( in the health club/spa area) unless we paid $35 each!!!! They said we could take a shuttle to the golf clubhouse and shower there. A Ritz Carlton would never have done that!

Reviews.Title: “A Failing Resort”
Reviews.Author: ajax4610
Reviews.Content: Stayed with my wife for 5 nights. My in-laws joined us for a day and a night. Iâ€™ll start with the good news. The food â€“ while it disappointingly does not reflect Puerto Rican culture in any way â€“ was well prepared, though wildly overpriced (as is consistently noted on Trip Advisor). We were upgraded and the room was well designed, clean and altogether pleasant. In the spirit of being constructive, Iâ€™ve organized my feedback into suggestions for the General Manager to improve the resort. They are: â€¢Intensively train and re-train your staff. They are nearly without exception pleasant, smiling and enthusiastic. They are also woefully undertrained. Waitresses donâ€™t know the menu and canâ€™t answer questions. Receptionists are slow and awkward. Our waiter at breakfast was overwhelmed by basic service: he gave us no water (we asked repeatedly), got no milk for my wifeâ€™s coffee (we asked repeatedly), and it took three requests to get our check. This pattern repeated itself over and over: nice employees without skills and seriously lacking a sense of urgency. â€¢Improve the check-in process. My wife and I waited more than 30 minutes, and my in-laws an outrageous 2+ hours to check in. The supercilious formality of the â€œsit downâ€� with the receptionist is both onerous and inefficient. We just want our key, not a briefing. â€¢Ensure rooms are available on time. We waited an hour for our room and my wifeâ€™s parents waited over 2 hours. On both occasions we were informed that the room was â€œstill being prepared.â€� â€¢Completely revisit your staffing model. We waited over an hour on two occasions for coffee from the supposedly instantaneous butler service; fortunately there were always four or more people at the front door and three or so greeters at the pool. I played golf and called for a shuttle when finished: after half an hour without it showing up I walked back to the hotel to discover two shuttle carts and abundant staff standing around the front door ready to dispense enthusiastic greetings. This is completely mismanaged personnel utilization. â€¢Clean and groom the beach. As noted on many Trip Advisor posts, the beach is dirty. It isnâ€™t a nice beach with its mud brown sand, but thatâ€™s beyond your control. The profusion of glass (dangerous) and other trash is well within your purview, and we observed detritus on the beach nearly every day. â€¢Kill the omnipresent soundtrack. The throbbing head music and Musak on the speakers that pervade every nook of the property are annoying. Worse, they actually kept my father-in-law awake when he tried to sleep with the patio door open. The resort presents itself as a bastion of natural beauty, then insists on drowning out the coqui frogs and other sounds of nature with house music. â€¢Keep the restaurants open. Sea Grapes restaurant was sometimes open, sometimes not. I assume it was closed when you judged hotel occupancy to be too low to support both it and Fern. Regardless, predictability is always helpful to guests trying to plan for meals. â€¢Improve poolside and beachside service. Poolside service needs to be much more diligent. Compared with the St Regis in Punta Mita where we stayed last May it is lacking in both attention and graciousness. When we wanted something we had to search for a waiter. â€¢Heat the pool. One felt like a Titanic survivor jumping into it, which naturally resulted in a nearly empty pool for our entire stay. Hard to see how you miss this one. â€¢Put screens on the patio doors. Seriously, you have no screen doors on the patios in the tropics! The mosquitoes are grateful. â€¢Donâ€™t work on the grounds first thing in the morning. Yes, industrious gentlemen were out using powered tools to cut vegetation and trim at 7:30 am. Spectacular wakeup. â€¢Mark Route 187 so people can find the resort. I know road signs arenâ€™t your responsibility, but we spoke to numerous people (including my in-laws) who drove by the resort more than once trying to find it â€¢Embrace Puerto Rico. As I mentioned, my wife and I stayed at the St. Regis Punta Mita and they have the same odd model: try to make the experience as culturally anonymous as possible, with an experience that replicates some island of Americana but for the accents of the employees. Why a Vongerichten restaurant instead of a high-end eatery focusing on local Puerto Rican cuisine? Why did the concierge (Kerryann?) direct my wife and me to Pasions at the grotesque Trump resort when we repeatedly asked for an authentic, local restaurant? Why did she put down local culture in her recommendation commentary? â€¢Management needs to get out there and see whatâ€™s going on. My father-in-law mentioned it first: you never see a manager walking around or soliciting feedback from guests. The juxtaposition of such a poorly run hotel and the utter lack of management presence was both galling and explanatory.

Reviews.Title: “80 degrees in January and still in the US--priceless”
Reviews.Author: buttercup16
Reviews.Content: One of my adult daughters and I stayed at the St Regis in Puerto Rico for several nights in January. We loved the hotel and we loved the beautiful weather. The hotel is lovely and the grounds are expansive. All the staff is very friendly. We loved the pool and the resort is right on the beach. We soaked in the sun, read books and went for several walks on the nature trails. We also enjoyed the spa. It opened this past November and although we loved our stay, there were a few kinks they need to work out.... but these kinks would definitely not keep me from going back. Room for improvement: 1. the shower in our room was huge (I didn't measure but about 11 by 11) but the water on both the rain shower nozzle and the shower head came out in a trickle. The water pressure is very low....if part of a luxury vacation for you includes a hot, steamy invigorating shower, you may need to pass on the hotel...maybe they were trying to conserve water? 2. The main dining room filled up for dinner reservations prior to our arrival. We were able to secure reservations for 9 pm the second night of our stay and, once we arrived, the hostess was flustered and said the kitchen was backed up and our dinner would be delayed.....it turned out okay but the dining room was only half full and it was one of only two options available for dinner....we ate in the dining room only once. The other options for food are the poolside restaurant which was actually very good and the golf area restaurant which has limited hours. We also ordered room service one night and it was good. As an aside, soft drinks are $5.00 each and each refill is the same...there is nowhere to purchase a soft drink except at one of the restaurants, the bar or the room refrigerator...they neglected to refill my room refrigerator after the first night and I am a Diet Coke addict so I had to go to the main lobby bar at 8 am each morning and order my $5.00 diet coke. Also, don't make the mistake of eating the tiny canister of chocolate covered raisins(or any of the other treats for that matter) in the room--that will set you back $17.00! 3. I was a little disappointed in housekeeping... I came back to the room at noon the first day and made a point of pushing the button to make sure we had our room serviced. I really like to come home to a straightened hotel room after a day of vacation...we arrived back at the room at 4 and still no housekeeping service.. I called and they came right away and the rest of the visit was much better. However, we did not receive turn down service except our last night and we were offered turn down service at 10:30 pm! Someone knocked on the door a few minutes after I had given a twenty dollar tip to the tv repair man and wanted to give us turn down service. We told them through the door that we were not interested. We never got our ice bucket refilled--even after I called and asked for a refill. I still would go back and plan to take my husband. It is very private and the grounds are gorgeous. I think they are trying very hard and I think they will improve over time.

Reviews.Title: “Anything you want... for a price.”
Reviews.Author: murphyswife
Reviews.Content: The St. Regis Bahia Beach is GORGEOUS and the service is GREAT! With that said, there is some room for improvement. The cost of food & beverage is very high, which after paying a high room rate will eventually double the cost of your trip. Also, if you did not rent a car the cost of transportation to locations outside of the resort are steep. I would not be writing if it weren't for the most recent high ticket item... a $168 transfer to the airport provided by First Class Transportation. A taxi is approximately $70 and was our first choice, but unfortunately the taxi service requires a cash only payment. This would not be a problem if the ATM at the St. Regis was not out of service for the past 3 days. Based on the level of service and accommodation that have been provided thus far I am surprised that the hotel is not offering to cover the difference. Although a good part of our stay here as been positive, the last memory will unfortunately be negative. I do recomend the St. Regis - highly, just be ready to pay a pretty penny.

Reviews.Title: “A Wonderful Experience!”
Reviews.Author: Tbreems230
Reviews.Content: My husband, two young adult children, and myself spent the last 5 days at the St. Regis and enjoyed every minute of it. From the champagne at check in, Mojitos prepared by our Butler, delicious meals, beautiful surroundings, GREAT golf, paddle boarding, fishing, biking, and many hours spent lounging by the pool....we loved it! The employees couldn't be more pleasant. Yes, they are still learning how to run a resort of the caliber of a St. Regis to it's full potential, but there is nothing comparable to a St. Regis on the Island. Service is slower at every restaurant on the Island. We have experienced the same on all the Caribbean islands; it's a way of life. We did rent a car at the airport and would suggest it if spending more than a couple of days there. Stop at a grocery store, visit some local spots, see how the locals live and appreciate all that life has offered you. We are thankful to have been able to spend quality time together as a family in such a beautiful part of God's world.

Reviews.Title: “Not a five-star experience”
Reviews.Author: WVKim2011
Reviews.Content: My husband and I chose the new St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort for our New Year's get away. Our expectation was high for a five-star property, but we were willing to be patient since the resort was so newly opened. We saw that the physical plant has the capability to deliver at a very high level. But the service! We couldn't have been more disappointed. Disappearing butlers, absent management, so much staff just standing around. There were plentiful greeters at the resort entrance but then none of them able to transport us to our distant room by golf cart (the only option apart from a long walk). Our concierge gave us wrong information on the resort's New Year's events. Also rented a car through the concierge and were told we could have done it cheaper on-line. Maps provided to local attractions and destinations were lifted from other resorts in locations distant from this one. Our room wasn't made up during the day on multiple occasions, with spotty turn-down service as well. Details were not attended to, specifically replacement of used items in the room such as glassware, robes, and some weren't provided at all, such as creamer for the coffee if you chose to use the coffeemaker in the room. Television options were disappointing as well. No HBO, etc. The spa experience was very nice and availability of services was good but very pricey. Regarding dining options on the property: prices charged for breakfast buffet for two at Seagrapes Restaurant ($88 with built-in service fee) was outrageous, and wine prices shocking ($60 for a bottle of wine we pay $18 for at home plus 22% service charge, 7% sales tax, and $5 delivery charge!). No water sports available at the beach at all. The surf was very rough and we never saw the aqua center open at any time during our stay. Since the pool was too cold for swimming, it seemed to force the children on the property into the small hot tub. It was filled with kids every time we ventured by. Pool cabana prices were crazy. We inquired about rentals and were told that they were $150 for a half day for a small cabana. Didn't bother to price a family cabana but at the price we were quoted for the small understood why they were all empty. Getting back to one's room at night on the beach side of the property was very challenging as there was no lighting whatsoever. We solved this by using the flashlight app on our i-phones. We also overheard enough other conversations between staff and other guests to know that they were having even more problems than we were, such as with keys and air conditioning that wouldn't work, etc.

Reviews.Title: “Disapointing”
Reviews.Author: PedroPortugal
Reviews.Content: This was my first stay in a St Regis and I had high expectations since I thought this brand, being on the top of Starwood chain, would compete with BanyaTree or Aman resorts. Well, only in price they compete. People from St Regis should spend a few nights in Amanyara (Turks and Caicos) or in any BanyanTree hotel and learn how to manage a luxury property...but let's go from the good to the bad: The good: the hotel is new, facilities are great and rooms are very spacious and well equipped. If you're a golfer this may be the right hotel for you since they have a gorgeous course. The not-so-good: the grounds are beautiful but location is not the best since this is the wettest and windiest area of Puerto Rico. The beach, although private, is not very good. The sand is dark and so is the water. Also, the ocean is quite rough so swimming or snorkeling is dangerous. The bad: 1. The swimming pools. it's beyond my understanding how they invested so many millions in building this resort and did not invest a few thousands in a temperature control system for the pools. The swimming pools are so cold that are always empty. And I mean freezing cold. I mean bone pain cold. So, if the sea is rough and pool is unusable - what kind of beach resort is this? 2. Food. For the price I expected superior, memorable food. ThatÂ´s not the case. Everything is too spicy, menus are very short and there are no daily specials for a change. Also the room service menu is a joke. 3. Service. I have to say that every single member of the staff was very friendly to us. That sort of compensates their inefficiency. We asked 3 times, 2 days in a row to replace our bath amenities that were finished. We asked the maid, asked the butler - the answer is always affirmative but nothing happens! When you call the concierge, you always get a voicemail to leave your message. You leave a message and nothing happens. I left a message to book table in main restaurant and never got answered back. I asked for assistance with the video on demand system - the butler service said they would send an engineer; we checked-out 3 days later and never saw the engineer. As asked twice for a taxi to take us back to airport at 2pm. Guess what: 2pm departure day and had to wait another 20 minutes for the taxi... 4. Resort fees. I don't want to sound arrogant, but if I'm paying 1000USD a night in high season to stay in a hotel, why do I have to pay another 60USD for wi-fi and towel service (the "resort fee")?? Obviously I would be willing to pay 60US more for the room rate - why don't they just add it up to the room price and not leave people with the feeling that they're just after your money...? This St Regis was a tremendous disappointment.

Reviews.Title: “St. Regis never falls short...Exceeded our expectations!”
Reviews.Author: gtrotter22
Reviews.Content: We had the best time at the St. Regis Bahia Beach. The property is immaculate, food is amazing, rooms are done nicely, and BUTLER service is AMAZING. They truly go above and beyond to make your stay a comfortable and memorable one. Please don't fall on the negative reviews posted here...these are the people who always like to complain for the little things and don't look at the big picture. Everything from the point of check-in, to the concierge service, to the misc. in-room requests, to the service by the pool, and service and food at Seagrapes and Fern were superb. I will definitely rate this as a FULL 7 star property.

Reviews.Title: “Definately not a St Regis Property”
Reviews.Author: Wallison
Reviews.Content: OK, I am 100% convinced that the positive articles on this site were written by hotel employees trying to salvage the reputation of this failing resort. I do understand that they have only been open for three months but there is no excuse for the level of service that has been displayed during our stay. I can honestly say that this is one of the most unpleasant experiences we have ever had on vacation, which is very unfortunate. We came with to the St Regis with the best of intentions to enjoy a much needed vacation from new york city and have are truly saddened that we chose this resort. We chose the St Regis because of the short flight time from New York. As we are traveling with friends and a 2 toddlers, we thought the flight time would be just right. That turned out to be a easy experience, checking in not-so-much. Before we arrived, I called 3 times to ensure that we would have cribs for the kids and adjoining rooms. When we arrived at 3 PM we were told our rooms were being finished and would be ready in 20 minutes. 2 1/2 hours later we were still waiting to get into our rooms. Once we did get into our rooms at 5:30, there were no cribs That proved to take 4 more hours and several calls to the "butler" and a $60 tip to make it happen. At arox 10 pm we had make shift pack and plays with no sheets set up in our rooms. Upon waking the next morning we learned that the only restaurant on site that is open mon-wed for Breakfast and dinner was the Fern. Again when I called several times prior to our arrival to inquire about dining situations for the kids, I was told there were two additional casual restaurants open daily. Certainly not the case. We ordered a glass of whole milk for room service this morning for my daughter and it was $14.38. Seriously, I speak the truth. As for dining, we had dinner at the Fern last night, we hired a sitter to watch our children so they wouldn't disturb other guest while dining. Again a waste since it is the only restaurant open, it was packed with children running around, crying, playing and chasing each other through the dining room while we attempted to enjoy our $375 dinner. Not exactly the romantic setting that is detailed online. The food is decent, but there are no award winners here. It is certainly not worth raving about. As for general service, there is absolutely no organization, follow through or training of the staff. We asked 4 people where the kids club was and not one person was able to tell us. Finally we walked to the reception desk and were told where it was. It is down a dirt road that was under construction. Not a great place for kids to be playing. The pool is absolutely freezing, not heated at all. The beach is not nice at all, and not a great swimming beach at all. ( this we knew before arriving) As for positives, Im finding them really hard to find. The grounds are nice, but not amazing. We have vacationed at Little Dix Bay in Virgin Gorda, The Amanyara Turks and Caicos, Caneel Bay, and the Westin in St John. All are far better options. This resort is three star at best. Not once has a manager address any of the problems with the quests. Every single person we have spoke to at the hotel has said that they are having a miserable time. You can't swim because the pool is cold, meals take 2/3 hours to get right, construction is going on everywhere are disturbing the peace. I will never return to recommend this resort to anyone. It has really been a horrible experience. I think that people should really review who is writing the positive reviews because I haven't spoken to one happy person.

Reviews.Title: “Should never have opened in high season....”
Reviews.Author: Seasonedpro23
Reviews.Content: Spent 8 nights at this hotel over Xmas. Simply put, the hotel is not ready to be opened as a five star hotel catering to the expectations of a five start consumer paying five star prices. Physical plant is quite nice, although beach debris is unconscionable for a property like this, and the service is liking sending lambs to slaughter. It is clear that the desire to maximize short term holiday revenues overrode any consideration about the longer term impact on the St. Regis brand. I think its safe to say that they have alienated the lions share of those who stayed here over that time period. If I were them, I would take a big step backward,keep occupancy low for an extended period of time, and invest in extensive training of the staff. I would also combine this with a letter of apology and some sort of financial remuneration for those who stayed during this time period. Simply unacceptable for what was being charged, and that includes room, food, golf, drinks etc. I am more than willing to pay top dollar when my expecations are met but when they are not, you have lost me forever and I venture to guess that most others who frequent these types of places feel the same way.

Reviews.Title: “I cried by the second day”
Reviews.Author: davndina
Reviews.Content: My family of five spent the week of Thanksgiving at the new St Regis in Bahia Beach. I was ready to leave and go back to the cold of PA by the second day. We stayed at the St Regis due to the outstanding service and facilities that the company has built it's reputation on-"to exceed the customer's expectations". The facility and the grounds are beautiful but the service was TERRIBLE!!!! One day I actually cried. We met with the manager midway through the trip and got lots of apologies for poor service, leaking AC that never got repaired, failure to move us to another room as we were told by management for over 4 hours, butler never to be seen, no newspaper the entire week, horrible poolside service, inability to fix meals or drinks on menus, etc. If we stayed in our room and didn't engage the staff or the resort services, things were ok because the staff and management COULD NOT DELIVER THE ST REGIS SERVICE. Do not spend the money, free nights, or SPG points on the facility. Starwood needs to get this place right or get rid of it!!!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Resort...But Hardly a St. Regis in Service...”
Reviews.Author: traveler1678
Reviews.Content: Incredibly beautiful resort -- I only wish they had invested in service and training a tiny fraction of what they did on the grounds. This was honestly one of the poorest service experiences I have ever had (I had better service at the JFK Airport Sheraton on my way to Puerto Rico) and the St. Regis should be ashamed for putting it's name and brand on this property. The butler service is a joke and it is amazing to see so many people doing absolutely nothing. Overall, an incredibly disappointing experience and one that I would not recommend to people looking for a luxury property,

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Trip -- Beautiful Resort”
Reviews.Author: Rdavid888
Reviews.Content: My wife and I had a fantastic trip. We did travel on points and free weekend awards. We stayed for 5 nights, were upgraded to an oceanfront suite (amazing). OK... More of the same here if you are reading all of these reviews. So, I am not going to expand upon many common points mentioned in previous reviews. Pro's: -Beautiful Property (well manicured and very spacious) -Nice Pool -Great Food (Fern for 1 dinner/breakfast & SeaGrapes a bunch) -Private -Room (Suite was amazing: HUGE bathrooms) -Location (direct flight, convenient location to other parts of Puerto Rico) -SPA (really nice, but expensive; I did massage and wife did facial, both awesome) -Complimentary Driving Range Privileges at Golf Course -Bikes/Boats and Bike Trails -Service (slow to meet special requests, but good overall) - Free Coffee Service in morning: Became a nice daily ritual for us; every morning waking up calling for coffee, sitting out on patio and shaking off the cobwebs with a cup of fresh joe overlooking the ocean Con's: -A/C: Yes, our Air Conditioner was quite loud. It blows down from above the bed (at least it does in the suite we were in). It sounds about as loud as a vacuum cleaner being on all night. See Tip #1 below. -Pricey: I agree with previous reviews; be prepared for high costs. $15 dollar drinks at pool and restaurants are expensive. Just part of the deal. See Tip #2 below -Limited Restaurant Options On-Site In contract to many other reviewers, we did not have any major service issues. In speaking with multiple butlers about this complaint, they are aware of the problem. They have had issues with phones and computers, which has been a bit of a problem. I think it is getting better. Overall, all employees of resort always had smile on their face and happy to help. Tip #1 (Air Conditioning): After the first night, we learned to turn the thermostat down to 65 for about 2-3 hours before bed; then turned it off and cranked the ceiling fan. It was very comfortable (quiet) sleeping. We bumped into some people that had no issues with AC, and others that did, so it must depend on the room. Tip #2 (Price): Eat out. There are some great restaurants around; many mentioned in previous reviews. The Kiosks in Luquillo (15-20 min drive) were nice. It is a row of restaurants and bars (attached to each other). Offer good, affordable food options. We had dinner at restaurant #2; liked it, but if we had it to do over again, would try one of the other places. We traveled off-site for dinner 2 of 5 nights; and wish we did it more. Pasta y Pueblo is a must do. #1 rated restaurant in Luquillo by Trip Advisor (not part of Kiosks: a traffic light or two past them). Picture a shack close to the beach, no matching chairs, silverware, etc. Some of the tables were standing up on 2 v 4's. Christmas lights running the top of the restaurant. Sits about 16-20 total people. BUT, the food is amazing, and SO inexpensive. We had coconut shrimp and the mahi mahi, both outstanding. Owner was super friendly, came out for a talk and asked us to sign his book. Cool experience, be prepared for something outside the norm. AND, a BYOB. Hard to find, so plug in their address to your phone navigation. Tip #3: Rent a Car: If you are staying more than 3 nights, you MUST rent a car. It made our trip so much more enjoyable. St Regis would prefer you take a taxi, so you are stuck and eat with them every night. Rio Grande is in a good location. 15 minutes from the Rainforest (we were going to go, but ran out of time; hear ziplines are awesome). 15 minutes from Luquillo (good food) and 30-40 minutes to Fajardo (Bio Luminescent Bay: also wanted to go, but it was a full moon when we were there, so passed on it). Tip #4: I-Phone: "Maps" Navigation: I have an iphone 4, the navigation through the Maps application worked great for our rental car. I would assume same for blackberry users. Tip #5: Directions to the resort from Airport: We got a little lost on our trip to the resort from the airport (and heard many others did as well). There is more than 1 turnoff for Rt 187 from Route 3. It is the 2ND light for Rt 187 (1st left after the Ralph's SuperMarket, which is on the right) Tip #6: Ralph's: One of the benefits of rental car is that we ran out to the local supermarket to get food. Picked up milk, mixers, wine, beer, snacks and breakfast food. It turned out to be an excellent move. We were happier to sit on our patio (oceanfront) and eat our own food in peace than going to Fern or SeaGrapes. Recommend you get checked in, get your bearings, and then make a run out to get your food. Improvements/Recommendations to St Regis: 1) Make Golf more affordable: I realize this is a "5 Star" property, but the cost was too high. I am a single digit handicap and play a lot of golf. $185 a round plus $65 rental clubs is too high. Yes, it is Robert Trent Jones course, and on the beach, and exclusive. But, they had 2 groups (total of 6 golfers) going out to play the ENTIRE day I went over to hit balls. It was an overcast day, but absolutely empty. Move it down to $150 including rental clubs; it will keeps the hacks away, and bring more good play to the course. 2) Valet Parking Cost: $22 a day for valet parking? The valet parking area could easily be offered as a service, but not mandatory. The lot where they take the cars is so close to the rooms. Would be more convenient to guests to just go get in their car, instead of calling and then waiting at the mainhouse, which we had to do every time. Isn't the $60/day resort cost enough? I just don't see the need for this expense. 3) Air Conditioning: It was not a huge deal, but I really would suspect that the engineer/architect that created the design is having to answer a few questions to hotel mgmt. It was startlingly loud. Again, like a constant running of a vacuum cleaner or a sound machine (for those of you with kids) running all night. The rooms are fabulous, that it particularly stood out that the AC was so noisy. Overall, we had a fantastic trip. For 5 nights, we ran up a bill of $1600 at check-out. I attached some pictures, hope they help. We hope to be back.... ENJOY!!

Reviews.Title: “wonderful ecological paradise with beautiful suites and wonderful food and sevice!”
Reviews.Author: nate10500
Reviews.Content: we stayed for a long weekend. december17 to 20th. our suite was exceptional-the linens and pillows were the softest -hard to get out of bed! our butler gave us the complimentary mojitos and ingedients for more. the commen spaces were elegant,warm,beautiful-more like a south seas paradise-original art and lighting. the restaurant destinations on the property were exceptional-breakfast on the second floor terrace in the main house is incomparable(service at all times was first class -breakfast,lunch and dinner). we did not golf,but the course reminded me of pebble beach-bring a lot of balls-there is water and wilddlife everywhere! we rode bycycles and kayacked the 500 beautiful acres of lush tropical landscape. we truely loved our stay and will be back soon.. we highly recomend the st regis in puerto rico!

Reviews.Title: “Nearly..almost...a great resort..”
Reviews.Author: lrob1450
Reviews.Content: Just returned from 4 lovely days at the resort..First, the positives. Physical layout of property is magnificent, exactly what I imagined it would be; the long, uncrowded beach is wonderful and I was in heaven when I walked on it in the mornings, and again in the afternoons..rooms are phenomenal--huge, very handsomely decorated, amazing beds and bathrooms..staff is, without exception, extremely courteous and friendly without being intrusive..food is good(but not great); pool is gorgeous...nature trails and boat house are lovely BUT: service is just not where a 5 star hotel needs to be--spotty, inconsistent...two of our 4 days our room hadn't been cleaned by 3pm; room service never got our orders exactly right, and then they never came back to clear (even after telling us they would be back in an hour); restaurant reservations were mixed up(although they made an excellent effort to get it straightened out); prices are JUST CRAZY for what you get--I expected, and don't mind, paying top dollar for my stays at Four Seasons, but this was MORE EXPENSIVE ($60 resort fees? Really???? Nearly $300 for a one hour massage???? $44 per person for a standard breakfast buffet?).Food at all the restaurants was expensive, and good, but not amazing(not even at Fern, Jean Georges' restaurant on property).I am confident that the St. Regis will achieve consistent service over the next couple of months (it is a BRAND NEW property), and it is the most beautiful resort I have been to in Puerto Rico(and I've been to the Ritz and the Wyndham Rio Mar, and the Hyatt El Dorado before it closed)...

Reviews.Title: “A Beautiful Experience”
Reviews.Author: holly063
Reviews.Content: Holly & I wanted to share a special and memorable experience while celebrating my 60th "B day. The Bahia Beach St. Regis truly was the right choice. The elegant Plantation style resort , gourmet dining and formal attention to service reminds you that you are at the 5 star top, ye, the tropical beach setting encourages you to let your hair down and and forget about formality and just relax. The almost deserted, expansive crescent beach is warm and inviting with coconut groves and rain forest mountains in the back ground. As nature lovers we were on sensory overload. Almost to much to take in, but we did, and can't wait to return. Oh, and the evenings, so romantic... Oh, and the evenings, so romantic...

Reviews.Title: “Nice Family Vacation”
Reviews.Author: DCTraveling
Reviews.Content: I just returned the other day for a 6 day, 5 night stay at the St Regis. I'll preface this review with the fact that I paid for my 5 night stay with a combination of "free nights" and starpoints, so I feel like I ultimately got a great value. I'm spg platinum and was not upgraded at check in. I stayed in a superior room, 811 which was wonderful. Not an ocean view, but the room itself was large and with the property being brand new, everything in the room was in good condition. The bathroom was enormous. So big that we were able to comfortably fit my daughter's crib in the shower area where she slept each night without a problem. We had a nice patio where we ate breakfast each morning along with the coffee provided by the hotel. I'd made a run to Ralph's supermarket to pick up a bunch of snacks, fruit, milk etc which I was able to eat for breakfast. Saved me $35 pp which is the adult buffet price. I think they also had a kids buffet for $25. Some folks had referenced a problem with the AC being loud. We didn't have an issue. We also live in a pre-war apt with window AC units so we might be used to some noise. The other couple we were with didn't have a problem w/ the AC either. The property is huge. Pool area has a great layout and you don't feel like you're on top of anyone else. Never a problem to secure chairs.....guess thats the benefit of staying at a hotel w/ only 139 rooms. As mentioned the pool is not heated (guessing this helped them get their Audobon green rating). Hot tub nice, but not overly hot. The kids pool was great. One of those declining pools that starts inches deep then flows into the regular pool. Was nice for the little ones to splash around in a totally safe spot. Beach was great. Not the white sand and crystal blue water, but huge and our daughter was able to run all over the place. The last few days we were there they'd set up a kids section w/ tons of new toys they'd apparently bought at a local toys r us. I think the sea water was a touch warmer than the pool water so I preferred to hang out there. I took two tennis lessons w/ Carl the director of tennis. He was awesome. Great guy who's taught many college players and some on the atp tour. Really helped my game in just two lessons. There are only two tennis courts and no pro shop. Would be great to see them build this up. Didn't play golf, but the course looked great. It was cloudy for 2 of our 6 days there, but the property is very expansive w/ great running and biking trails along with a boathouse where you can use non-motorized boats for free. Bikes are also free to use. The only complaints I'd have about the hotel is the restaurant & maid/butler service. One day I had to call "butler service" 4 times for a bottle opener. You'd think they'd rush this over as not having a bottle opener precludes you from purchasing items in the mini-bar. I had to call my butler Ricardo on his personal cell before I got it. Also, room make up and turn down service was non-existant some days and I had to call for it. That was a bit frustrating. Regarding the restaurants, there are only a few options, Seagrapes (by the pool), Fern (jean georges) and Molasses (at the golf course). I think seagrapes/fern are always open, but Molasses only some days. Ask the receptionist at check in for details. Seagrapes - was good for lunch. food is not cheap, but i thought it was great. service was adequate for lunch. for dinner it was different story. we went there 1 night and our waitress didn't introduce herself for 10 minutes, then proceeded to mess up the majority of the entrees. we had 2 crying toddlers so we like to eat and run and the server didn't help. they did wind up comping our bill that night which was great. we just didn't return for dinner. Fern - nice dining room and i thought the food was good. ate here 3 times during my stay and the 3rd time was NOT THE CHARM. as mentioned we were with 2 toddlers. this is typically a nicer restaurant than we'd go to w/ our child, but as mentioned seagrapes took themselves out of the dining picture. we ordered the entrees and the girls got a bit restless at which point the manager came over to us and said "we try to keep a certain ambience at this restaurant, so please try and keep your kids quiet" this guy must be from a different planet to think you can simply tell a 15 month old to keep quiet and they act accordingly. this made a very uncomfortable situation for all of us and put a damper on the evening. Molasses (at the golf clubhouse)- this is the best spot to eat at, but i think its only open a few nights a week. our server, Braulio i think, was great. taught us a lot about the local cuisine, current events and sporting news and was so quick to react to anything we wanted while eating there. He was the most attentive employee we came into contact with our entire stay. Ultimately a great stay b/c the property is expansive and luxurious, quality of actual food was good and the room was perfect. I'm sure the service kinks (and some employees) will be optimized out. Hoping I can return in the future when the St Regis is firing on all cylinders. p.s. they have a s'mores cookout and champagne tasting on the weekend nights (both are free). we were not informed at check-in so we missed the s'mores event.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing facilities, service and food. Not so great beach.”
Reviews.Author: International_Baller
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the St Regis Bahia Beach the weekend of Dec 18th for our babymoon. We stayed on points and starwood's free weekend award, since I'm a platinum member we were able to be upgraded to an oceanfront room, room 311. Overall the place was amazing and I highly recommend it especially if you're coming from the east coast as it's such a short flight. Pros: 1. Top notch facilities in everyway. The bathroom of our room might have been the nicest one I've ever stayed in at any hotel. Two different shower heads, tons of space, jacuzzi....amazing! The room also had a walk in closet and private patio with a view of the beach. 2. Everything is brand new and nice. The club house, lobby, restaurants, even the gym was in great shape. Can't say the same for other 5 stars with years of use, but take advantage of this while you can. 3. Food was amazing, especially at Fern, where we ate twice. Yes, everything here is overpriced as many have complained but guess what? You're staying at a 5 star resort. If you don't like it, book at holiday inn and shut up. I didn't like paying 5 bucks for a bottle of water but I did like the army of people there to serve me. Cons: 1. Because it's new, they have to work on a few kinks. The movie in our room never worked even though we were told we would get one for free per night, I called each night to let them know about this issue and it neve got fixed. They even charged me for the movie for each night but after calling in they quickly fixed it. Not a big deal, but there are definite service isssues they have to work on. 2. The beach really blows. As many have pointed out, this is not a true Carribbean beach which is why I didn't give it 5 stars. We stayed by the pool the whole time which was fine. Also I played the golf course which was super nice. I'm a 12 handicap and had no problem playing fromthe tees in front of the tips. Overall highly recommend and will return after I check out some other hotels with nicer beaches.

Reviews.Title: “Most enjoyable”
Reviews.Author: Jason_Lee064
Reviews.Content: My partner and I traveled to Puerto Rico for a quick vacation and thought we'd try out the new St Regis resort. Like other reviewers stated, I was a bit apprehensive about trying a new hotel in the Caribbean, But we were pleasantly surprised. By no means was the service up to a five star level, but it was certainly the friendliest four star service I have received in the Caribbean. The staff genuinely cares and went out of their way to makes us happy. I just hope that all the Northerners coming down for Christmas don't hurt the humbleness of the staff. I would highly recommendly this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Extraordinary!!”
Reviews.Author: YYCM
Reviews.Content: The hotel is brand new, the rooms are beautiful, very clean. It is a very beautiful place with a lot of nature around: natural trails in which you can walk, jog, run or go in bicycles at the same time you admire the different plants, animals and lakes that are there. All the facilities are amazing and the service is incomparable, very friendly pleople always willing to help you and making your stay unforgettable. It's a little expensive (it's a 5 star) but every dollar is worth it.

Reviews.Title: “Potentially a great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: piatty73
Reviews.Content: I am sitting in my room on our last night of a 3 night stay. We are having room service because the only place open tonight is Fern, we ate there last night and it is just ok and not really a Jean George experience. Let me start with the drive. I called the hotel and was emailed directions that were perfect and it was an easy drive with no trouble finding the hotel. Check-in: It took about 30min because I reserved a ocean front king and while I appreciated the upgrade they gave us a larger room with a garden view. We wanted to be on the ocean and it took a half hour to figure out there were no ocean view rooms available. We were moved back to my original room for the rest of the stay. I recommend the ocean rooms over the garden even if the garden room is larger. The sound of the ocean with the sounds of nature are great. Rooms: the first suite had a very loud a/c unit and we discovered that you can have engineering set for VIP so that you can take it off the program mode and cool it down more. For those of us that live in hot humid climates like Houston, we are sensitive about a/c. The rooms have a humidity problem and it is not summer yet. The ocean room had a quieter a/c but still humid. The bathrooms are fantastic but we had an issue with hot water one night until we discovered that you need to turn on the handheld shower along with the rain shower for it to get hot. We loved the balcony looking and listening to the ocean. Food: I am not shocked by prices in resorts like this. You have to realize it will be that way. As stated we were not impressed with Fern, the breakfast there is pretty good with an amazing french toast dish. Molasses at the golf course was best with regional cuisine that we enjoyed and would have returned except it is closed on Mon and Tues. Service: I agree with almost all that has been said. The staff is very friendly, they just don't seem to have been trained very well. We were told to go to Loquilla Beach for snorkeling and we could pick up the gear at the boathouse on drive out. There was no one at the boathouse for about 15min and then a mgr and an employee arrived and we were told they do not have snorkeling equip and after several phone calls they could not find any. We also found the directions from concierge to be incorrect but it was easy to find. The snorkeling there was non-existant and I do not recommend going there to eat either. When we left and returned to the property and went to the beach the attendant told us the stuff was at the beach shack there. He brought us new sets as well as boogey boards. Some staff were not sure when different restaurants were open or closed including concierge. Calling is a problem and you find no answer many times. One morning our pre-ordered coffee arrived on time, the next day it did not arrive without a phone call 30min after it should have been there. If you look at the Ritz San Juan reviews you see some of the same service problems. It may be a culture problem here. The property is beautiful and we may return if I read the issues have been addressed.

Reviews.Title: “Kinks have been worked out! Go and enjoy yourself.”
Reviews.Author: Ginlis
Reviews.Content: Wow - what a place! We loved it. Pros: Spectacular rooms! Giant rooms with all the amenities. The bathroom was huge with a walk in shower and an oversized tub. This was so cool - the bathroom mirror had a television built into it. You could watch the today show while shaving! Not necessary, but very, very cool. Complimentary coffee delivery in the morning. We had brought our own cereal and yogurt and the hotel delivered coffee and milk and we had breakfast on our patio for free. The pool is outstanding. Super comfortable lounge chairs, great service, lots of places to sit and it did not feel crowded. We saw the pool manager the last day and asked her to consider making the pool a no cell phone area as there were at least 3 people on long business calls sitting at the pool. The beach is clean, large and not crowded. We could walk both directions for quite a ways and really enjoyed the beach. The property has a walking path and nature path that are well marked, easy to follow, long enough to feel like a workout (3 miles) and you see some terrific greenery. The golf course looked very nice. Food and drinks were terrific. We ate at the pool, at the casual restaurant and at the upscale restaurant. All were delicious and yes - what everyone says about cost is true. We saved some money by ordering kids meals at the pool - more than enough food and nothing wrong with chicken fingers and cheeseburger sliders! Yes, there is free water and fruit in the work out room and the hotel has a number of complimentary events that include snacks - welcome mojitos in your room, champagne tasting at the bar, smore's on the beach, tastes of drinks at the pool, etc, etc, etc. The staff was super nice and competent. Our key did not work one night and we called the front desk and asked them to send someone. We asked that the person come right away - and as we hung up the phone saw a person running (yes running) towards our room to open the door. Cons Yes, the drive is confusing to get to the hotel. Get good, accurate directions before embarking. By the way, this is only a few moments of your entire trip so why stress so much over it? The only other con is that this place is going to become very popular and Starwood will make it less available to those of us on points!
